chunks.original_latin:
IX. Tito pontifici  interroganti per epistolam, quae sapientiae
domus, quis crater, et qui cibi et potus.
chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
    Nine<break time="500ms"/>
        <s>
            Titus the priest wrote a letter asking about the house of wisdom, the cup, the food, and the drink.
        </s>
<break time="1s"/>
</speak>

Saint Timothy responds, "Dear Titus, I'm not sure if any theological symbols known to me have been overlooked."

In symbolic theology, we recognize that discussions about God are often complex. Indeed, when purifying souls from imperfections, wise fathers reveal divine and mystical truths through hidden and bold riddles that aren't accessible to the impure.

Therefore, we don't rely heavily on rational explanations of divine mysteries. We understand them through symbols that are natural and perceptible to us. However, it's necessary to see these symbols in their pure form. In doing so, they reveal a fountain of life within, standing on its own, a singular power that acts independently, upholding the knowledge of all knowledge, and contemplating by itself.

We believe it is essential for us and others to replicate the varied symbolic forms of sacred representation about God. Otherwise, everything becomes filled with incredible and fictitious monstrosities, like the super-essential divine generation reshaping the womb of God to give birth physically, or the word emanating into the air from a manly heart, or describing the spirit breathed from the mouth, and bosoms pregnant with God praising God the Son physically to us, or depicting these things in stages, and presenting certain trees, shrubs, flowers, roots, or fountains of water flowing forth, or brightness generating lights, or other such manifestations of super-essential theological sacred descriptions.
chunks.original_latin:
Sanctus quidem Timotheus, o bone Tite, nescio
an quid cognitorum mihi theologicorum symbolorum
recessit relinquens. Sed in symbolica theologia
bene discrevimus, omnes eloquiorum de Deo aestimationes
esse multis monstruosas. Etenim in consequentia
contaminatam extergentes imperfectionibus
animarum, quandocunque arcanae sophiae patres
 per quaedam occulta et audacia aenigmata manifestant
divinam, et mysticam, et inviam immundis veritatem. Propterea non credimus multi de divinis
mysteriis rationibus. Contemplamur enim solummodo
ea cum connaturalibus nobis sensibilibus symbolis. Oportet autem et exuentes ea in semetipsis nuda
et pura facta videre. Sic enim in contemplantibus
aperirent  quidem fontem vitae in seipsum fusum,
et in seipso stantem videntes, et unam quandam
virtutem, simplam, per seipsam motam, per seipsam
operantem, seipsam non deserentem, sed scientiam
omnium scientiarum subsistentem, et semper per
seipsam contemplantem. Oportere igitur et ipsi et
aliis apud nos aestimavimus, quantum possibile esset,
replicare variabiles deformitates de Deo symbolicae
 sacrae figurationis. Quod enim extra eam hoc
omni repletur incredibili et fictiformi monstrositate,
utpote in superessentiali quidem divina generatione,
ventrem Dei corporaliter Deum gignentem reformantis,
et verbum in aëra profusum ex corde virili
eructantis ipsum, et spiritum exspiratum ab ore describentis,
et sinus Deo fecundos gremio gestantes,
Deum filium corporaliter nobis laudantis, aut plantatim
haec figurantis, et arbores quasdam et frutices
 et flores et radices praemittentis, aut fontes aquarum
emanantis, aut claritatibus processivas luminis
generationes, aut alias quasdam superessentialium
theologicorum manifestorias sacras descriptiones.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Concerning the unseen aspects of God's providence—like gifts, manifestations, powers, characteristics, impacts, dwellings, processions, discernments, and unities—human imagination often envisions God in animals, plants, and various stones. These are adorned with imagery like women's garments or barbaric weaponry. It's as if a craftsman adds pottery or metalwork, placing horses, chariots, and thrones beneath them, and preparing daily meals, transforming them to drink, become drunk, sleepy, and intoxicated.

What if someone mentions anger, sadness, oaths, madness, curses, fury, misleading promises of sin, and the battle of giants in Genesis, where it's said that those powerful men acted out of fear? This construction wasn't meant to harm others, but for their salvation, scheming, and that counsel set up near the sky in Ahab's deception, along with the material and adulterous passions in songs, and other bold divine compositions, sacredly assembled. These are declarations of hidden problems, multiplied and partial unities, lacking parts, and figurative and multifaceted forms and figures.

If anyone could see the hidden beauty within, they would find everything mystical and divine, filled with much theological light. We don't believe that these compositions are reformed for their own sake, but are laid out before the pretended, with much invisible knowledge, so that the most sacred things aren't easily accepted by the impure. They're revealed only to sincere lovers of divinity, as forming every childish imagination into sacred symbols, and to those capable of transcending with simplicity of mind, and with the opportunity for contemplative virtue, towards the simple, supernatural, and preeminent truth of the symbols.
chunks.original_latin:
Deinde invisibilium Dei providentiarum, aut donorum,
aut manifestationum, aut virtutum, aut proprietatum,
percussionum, aut mansionum, aut processionum,
aut discretionum, aut unitatum, humanum
figmentum Deo et bestiarum, et animalium
aliorum, et germinum, et lapidum variam formationem
circumfingentis, et ornatus ei muliebres, aut
barbaricas armorum facturas circumponentis, figulariam
aut conflatoriam, ut artifici cuidam, apponentis,
et equos et currus ei et thronos substernentis,
et quotidianas escas quasdam pulmentificas
 praeparantis, et bibentem, et inebriatum, et somnolentum,
et crapulatum transformantis. Quid si
quis dicat iras, tristitias, varia juramenta, insanias,
maledictiones, furores, multiformia et obliqua repulsionis
peccati promissionum sophismata, in Genesi
gigantum pugnam, per quam deliberare ex timore
dicitur potentibus illis viris, hanc aedificationem
non injuria quorumdam aliorum, sed pro salute
eorum machinantibus, et consilium illud juxta
caelum in dolo et seductione Achab paratum, et canticorum
materiales et adulteras multas passiones, et
quaecunque alia omnia audacis sunt divinae formationis
sacre composita declarativa occultorum problemata
et multiplicata et partia unitatum et carentium
partibus, et figurativa et multiformia carentium
 formis et figuris? Quorum si quis videre potuerit intus
occultam pulchritudinem, inveniet mystica et
deiformia omnia, et multi theologici luminis repleta. Non enim arbitramur manifesta compositorum
propter seipsa reformari, praetendi autem ante praetenta,
et invisibili multa scientia, ut non immundis
facile accepta sint sacratissima. Solis autem revelentur
divinitatis sinceris amatoribus, tanquam
omnem puerilem phantasiam in sacris symbolis formantibus,
et idoneis transcendere simplicitate animi,
et contemplativae virtutis opportunitate, ad simplam
et supernaturalem et praecollocatam symbolorum
veritatem.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
It's important to recognize that among theologians, there are two traditions: one is secretive and mystical, while the other is clear and more widely known.

The first tradition is symbolic and transformative, whereas the second is philosophical and affirming, covering both the expressible and the inexpressible. Some concepts endure and require the truth of spoken words, while others operate in silence, placing God within the unspeakable teachings of doctrine.

According to the sacred mysteries of the saints, none of our sacred teachers in the legal tradition of divine symbols have been absent. We also witness the most sacred angels conveying divine enigmas mystically, with Jesus himself speaking in parables and delivering divine mysteries through symbolic meals.

It was appropriate that not only the pure holy of holies should be preserved by many, but also that human life, in its indivisible and undivided form, should be illuminated by divine knowledge. This imperishable part of the soul is meant to separate into simple and direct visions of godlike forms.

The perishable part, however, serves naturally and extends into the most divine prearranged formations of symbolic representations. Those who create such veils and manifest them, by leaving behind the outer layers of theology, reform within themselves a likeness that leads to an understanding of theology.

This visible creation of the universe is a reflection of the invisible God, as Paul explains, and it embodies true reason. Therefore, theologians interpret some things in a civil and legal manner, while others are seen in a purifying and uncontaminated way. Some aspects are considered humanly and moderately, while others are viewed in a supermundane and perfect manner.

Drawing from both the laws of revealed truths and the laws of hidden truths, they follow sacred writings, understandings, and souls. It doesn't just have a mere historical narrative but possesses a vital perfection, presented to them as a whole, embodying reason in everything.
chunks.original_latin:
Sed itaque et hoc intelligere oportet, duplicem
esse theologorum traditionem: unam quidem
arcanam et mysticam, alteram vero manifestam
 et notiorem: et eam quidem symbolicam et
perfectivam, hanc vero philosophicam et approbativam,
et complectitur effabili ineffabile. Et aliud quidem
patitur et indiget dictorum veritatis: hoc vero
agit et collocat Deo ineffabilibus doctrinae introductionibus. Et quidem neque secundum sanctorum
mysteriorum teletas alii secundum nos, alii legalis
traditionis sacri magistri divinorum defuere symbolorum:
sed et sacratissimos angelos per aenigmata
divina mystice producentes videmus, et ipsum Jesum
in parabolis theologantem, et deifica mysteria tradentem
 per typicam coenam. Etenim erat consequens,
non solum incontaminata multis salvari sancta
sanctorum, sed et hoc humanam vitam non partibilem
simul et non partitam subsistentem, proprie
seipsa divinas illuminari scientias: et hoc quidem
impassibile animae in simpla et intima deiformium
agalmatum segregare spectacula. Passibile autem
ejus connaturaliter famulari simul et extendi in divinissima
praemachinatis typicorum symbolorum
performationibus, sic cognata hujusmodi genuit velamina
et declarant quicumque et ante velamina
extra theologiam manifestam relinquentes, in seipsis
reformant similitudinem quandam ad intelligentiam
se dictae theologiae manuducentem. Et haec visibilis
universitatis mundi factura, invisibilis Dei praemissa
 est, sicut ait Paulus, et vera ratio. Proinde et theologi
quaedam quidem civiliter et legaliter inspiciunt,
quaedam autem purgative et incontaminate: et
quaedam quidem humanitus et medie, quaedam autem
supermundane et perfective: et tum quidem ex
legibus manifestatorum, tum vero ex occultorum
legibus secundum consequentiam suppositis sacris
literis et intellectibus et animabus. Non enim historiam
nudam, sed vitalem habet perfectionem praeposita
eis simul omnis, et per omnia ratio.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
For the sake of popular acceptance, it's important for us to openly embrace the holy beauty of sacred symbols. We shouldn't disregard them, as they are essential for depicting divine characters and the visible images of mysteries and supernatural contemplations.

Indeed, not only are the superessential lights and invisible things represented symbolically, like the supernatural God being referred to as fire and the invisible words of God being fiery. Moreover, the divine adornments of invisible and intellectual angels are described in various forms and fiery representations.

We need to understand the image of fire differently according to the superintelligence of God: differently according to its invisible providences or reasons, and differently in angels. One according to cause, another according to subsistence, and another according to participation, and others differently based on this theory and the order set by intention.

It's important not to confuse sacred symbols, but to apply them appropriately to causes, subsistences, virtues, orders, or dignities: to replicate those that are clearly composed.

To avoid stretching beyond necessity in these matters, we already know what's at hand. We say that all food is perfective for those being nourished, filling their imperfections and needs, healing the weak, preserving life, making them flourish, renewing them, and providing vital benefits, while simply rejecting what is distressing and imperfect, granting joy and perfection.

Therefore, the superwise and best wisdom is rightly praised by these words, setting up a mystical cup and pouring out sacred drink for them, but even more so by offering solid food before these, with a lofty proclamation, desiring those who desire it most beautifully.

Therefore, divine wisdom offers a double portion of food: one solid and edible, and the other liquid and abundant, extending its provident goodness in a cup.
chunks.original_latin:
Oportet
igitur et nos, pro populari de ipsis susceptione, palam
sacrorum symbolorum sanctam pulchritudinem permittere,
et non spernere ea, divinorum cum sint
characterum poscere formationes, et imagines manifestae
arcanorum et supernaturalium speculaminum. Etenim non solum  superessentialia lumina, et
invisibilia, et simpliciter divina typicis pervariantur
symbolis, sicut supernaturalis Deus ignis dictus, et
invisibilia Dei eloquia ignita. Insuper autem et
invisibilium simul et intellectualium angelorum
deiformes ornatus variis formis describuntur, et
multis speciebus et igneis figurationibus . Et aliter
oportet eandem ignis imaginem juxta superintelligentiam
Dei dictam excipere: aliter autem secundum
ipsam invisibilium ejus providentiarum aut rationum:
et aliter in angelis. Et eam quidem secundum
causam, istam vero secundum subsistentiam,
hanc vero secundum participationem, et alia aliter
secundum haec theoria et disciplinalis  ordinatio
intentionem ponit. Et non ut consequebantur sacra
 symbola confundere, sed convenienter ea causis, aut
subsistentiis, aut virtutibus, aut ordinibus, aut dignitatibus:
replicare, quorum sunt manifestatoria
composita. Et ut non ultra quod oportet extendamus
in ipsis, jam proposita nobis quaestio scienda. Et
dicimus, quia omnis esca perfectiva est nutriendorum,
imperfectionem eorum et indigentiam replens,
et infirmum curans, et vitam eorum custodiens, et
florere faciens, et renovans, et vitale eis beneficium
donans, et simpliciter contristantem et imperfectum
respuens, et laetitiam eorum et perfectionem  largiens. Bene igitur supersapiens et optima sophia
ab eloquiis laudatur, cratera mysticum statuens, et
sacrum eis potum profundens, magis autem ante
hos solidas escas proponens, et cum excelsa praedicatione
ipsa desiderantes se optime et pulchre
desiderans. Duplicem igitur escam divina sapientia
proponit: unam quidem solidam et manducabilem,
alteram vero humidam et profusam, et in cratere
porrigit providas suas bonitates.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The round and expansive bowl symbolizes an all-encompassing providence that has no beginning and is infinite. It extends into everything while remaining within itself, standing in the unchanging likeness of nature, perfectly placed, uniformly, and immovably, just like the bowl stands.

Moreover, wisdom is said to build a house for itself, offering solid food, drink, and the bowl. This clearly reveals divine symbols to those who act divinely, because the most perfect providence is the cause of all existence and well-being. It extends into everything, becomes everything, and contains everything, yet remains exalted above all. It is nothing in nothing by nothing but exists eternally, standing and remaining in itself forever in the same way.

It exists without being made outside itself, neither abandoned by its own gravity, unchangeable stance, nor goodness. It works the most complete and perfect providences within itself, coming into everything, remaining in itself, always standing and moving, neither standing nor moving.

If anyone says that providential actions in standing and providing occur simultaneously, both naturally and supernaturally. But what is solid food, and what is liquid? The best wisdom is praised for providing these. I believe the solid food carries the essence of intellectual and nurturing perfection, and natural immutability, through which divine things were established. It shares powerful, uniform, and inseparable knowledge with the intellectuals of sensible things, to whom the wisest Paul, drawing from wisdom, truly delivers solid food.

The liquid, however, flows abundantly into everything with rushing strength, and through various and many divided ways, leading those nurtured into simple and unwavering divine knowledge, guided by goodness.
chunks.original_latin:
Ipse igitur crater
rotundus dum sit et repandus, symbolum sit expansae
simul et in omnia circumeuntis sine principio et
infinitae horum omnium providentiae. Verumtamen
quoniam in omnia proveniens, manet in seipsa, et
stat in immutabili naturae similitudine, et perfectissima
irremeabiliter seipsa collocata uniformiter et
 fixe, sic crater stat. Aedificans autem et sapientia
domum sibi dicitur, et in ipsas solidas escas et potus
et cratera proponens: sic esse divina divinitus
symbola facientibus clarum, quia et providentia perfectissima
est ipse essendi et bene essendi omnia
causalis, et in omnia procedit, et in omni fit, et
continet omnia, et iterum ipse in eodem per excellentiam,
nullum in nullo per nullum est, sed exaltatur
omnibus, ipse in seipso similiter et aeternaliter
ens, et stans, et manens, et semper secundum eadem
et sicsic habens, et nullo modo extra seipsum
factus, neque propria gravitate et incommutabili
mansione et bonitate relictus: sed et in seipsa 
totas et perfectissimas providentias optime operans,
et proveniens in omnia, et manens in seipso, et
 stans semper et motus , neque stans, neque motus . Sed o si quis dixerit providas operationes in mansione,
et mansionem in providendo connaturaliter
simul et supernaturaliter habens. Sed quae solida
esca, et quae humida? Has enim optima sapientia
donare simul et providere laudatur. Ipsam quidem
solidam escam compositionem gestare arbitror intellectualis
et nutritoriae perfectionis, et naturalis
immutabilitatis, secundum quam divina constiterunt,
et potentem et uniformem et inseparabilem
scientiam participant cum intellectualibus sensibilium
illorum, quibus sapientissimus Paulus ex sapientia
accipiens, vere solidam escam tradit . Humidam 
autem perfuse simul et in omnia provenire festinantis
virtutis, et adhuc per varia et multa et partita,
 in simplam et non tremulantem divinam cognitionem
nutritos familiares  ipsis bonitate manuducentis.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Because of this, divine and invisible words are imagined as dew, water, milk, wine, and honey due to their life-giving abundance. Like water, they have strength; like milk, they are nourishing; like wine, they are revitalizing; and like honey, they are both purifying and preserving.

Divine wisdom generously grants these to those who come, providing abundant feasts without ever running out. This is truly feasting, and for these reasons, it is praised as life-giving, nurturing to the young, renewing, and perfecting.

In this sacred revelation of feasting, even God, the cause of all good things, is said to be intoxicated by the fullness and understanding of the feast. Or rather, we might say, the drink of God's feast is the most perfect and indescribable immeasurable abundance.

Just as for us, intoxication is an excessive filling and an ecstatic state of mind and senses, so in God, intoxication is understood as nothing other than the superabundance and source of all good things beyond measure.

The result of this intoxication is an ecstasy of wisdom, a supreme understanding of God, where understanding is exalted by comprehending beyond comprehension, beyond being itself. God is the best of everything, intoxicating and satisfying, as the excellence of the immeasurable universe of all perfect plenitude, and again, the summit above all.

From this, those who wish to partake in the feasts in the kingdom of God's saints will do so in the same way. As it says, the King himself will make them recline and will serve them.

These signify a common and equally invisible fellowship of the saints in divine goods, the Church of the firstborn enrolled in heaven, and the spirits of the saints perfected in all good things, filled first with the best.
chunks.original_latin:
Propter quod et rore, et aqua, divina et invisibilia
eloquia, et lacte et vino, et melle adimaginantur,
propter vitae fecundam eorum, ut in aqua,
virtutem: et auctivam, ut in lacte: et revivificativam,
ut in vino: et purgativam simul et custoditivam,
ut in melle. Haec enim divina sapientia donat
 provenientibus copiose eis, et non deficientibus epulis
affluentia largiente et supermanante. Hoc autem
vere epulari, et propter haec vivificatrix simul et
parvulorum nutrix, et renovatrix, et perfectrix laudata. Secundum hanc autem sacram epulationis
apertionem, et ipse omnium bonorum causalis Deus
inebriari dicitur, propter superplenitudinem et intelligentiam
epulationis: aut potus dicendum, epulationis
Dei perfectissimam et ineffabilem deterius immensurabilitatem. Ut enim in nobis secundum quod
ebrietas immoderata repletio est, et mente et sensibus
ecstasis, sic secundum quod melius, in Deo ebrietatem
non aliud quid oportet intelligi, praeter
superabundantiam et causam provenientem in ipso
omnium bonorum immensurabilem. Sed et consequens
 ebrietatis sapientiae ecstasis, supereminens
Dei superintelligentia intelligenda, secundum quam et
exaltatur intelligendo superintelligere ens, et superintelligitur
et super ipsum esse, et ipse omnium,
quaecunque sunt, optima inebrians simul et satians
est Deus, tanquam omnium ipsorum simul et superplenorum
immensurabilis universitatis superexcellentia,
et iterum extra et summitas omnium sursum
positus. Ab his autem volentes et in regno Dei sanctorum
convivia juxta eundem accipiemus modum. Transiens enim, ait, ipse rex discumbere eos faciet,
et ipse ministrabit eis . Significant autem haec
communem quandam et aeque invisibilem sanctorum
in divinis bonis societatem, et Ecclesiam primogenitorum
descriptorum in caelis, et spiritus sanctorum
 omnibus optimis perfectos, et primum optimis
repletos.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
We see rest as a relief from many pains, a life untouched by harm, and a divine interaction filled with sacred meaning in the light and realm of the living, abundant with generous and blessed gifts. Through these, everyone finds joy.

It is a time to rejoice, with Jesus guiding them to relax, serving them, granting eternal rest, and sharing the fullness of blessings.

I am well aware of the investigation and the blessed rest of God, and the awakening that has been revealed. When we say the divine rest is distant from God and not shared with those provided for; being vigilant is to offer them teaching or assist those praying for salvation.

Many theological symbols have been left out. Thus, considering it unnecessary to repeat the same things to the same people, other matters are considered. Meanwhile, you should follow the good teachings, recognizing the writings, and we rest from what has been said, surpassing, I believe, what our writings owe.

Yet we send this entire symbolic theology of ours, through which you will discover the house of wisdom with its seven well-defined columns, its solid nourishment divided into incense and bread, and what is the moderation of wine, and again, what is the intoxication from God's abundance. These things are explained more fully within it.

It is, I believe, the finest creator of all symbolic theologies, fitting to the sacred traditions and truths of the teachings.
chunks.original_latin:
Et recubitum requiem arbitramur multis
doloribus vitam illaesam, et conversationem divinam
in lumine et regione viventium, omni sensu
sacro repletam, et largissimorum et beatorum optimorum
copiosam dationem, per quam laetitia omni
replentur. Hoc autem est laetari, Jesu recumbere
eos faciente, et ministrante, et aeternam requiem
donante, et plenitudinem bonorum distribuente simul
et infundente. Inquisitionem vero bene scio, et
benedictum somnum Dei, et evigilantiam aperuisse,
cum dicimus, divinum somnum esse remotum
Dei, et incommunicabile provisis: vigilare autem,
in providendum eos doctrina, aut salute deprecantibus
succursum. Multa autem theologica symbola
 praetermissa. Ideo superfluum arbitrantes esse, eadem
eisdem revolventes alia videri, simul etiam
vobis in bonis obediendum, et cognoscentes quae
quidem sunt epistolae, ab his quae dicta sunt, quiescimus,
excedentes, ut aestimo, in plus quam nostris
literis debita. Hanc autem totam nostram symbolicam
theologiam mittimus, per quam invenies cum
sapientiae domo  et columnas septem bene discretas,
 et solidam escam ejus in thymiamata et panes
divisa, et quae vini temperantia, iterumque quae ab
ebrietate Dei crapula. Et haec quae nunc dicta, latius
in ea declarantur. Et est, ut arbitror, omnium symbolicarum
theologiarum inventrix optima, et conveniens
eloquiorum sacris traditionibus et veritatibus.
